> Cookie time.



"My work asks questions, it never has answers." -{{champion:202}} 

https://imgur.com/be8LI6P

Is this..........really how the cookie crumbles?

This is extremely interesting, and a very good find.

I've always suspected this as well, especially when he says very peculiar quotes like "You only understand harmony.  Discord is required for contrast," and the like, but now that we've essentially gotten a confirmation from a Rioter, there's a lot to dig into and speculate now.

Overall, it sounds like Jhin seems to seriously despise Ionian society to such a huge extent that he willingly wants to drive people insane through his artwork so that they can finally be "free" from the nation's restrictive and dehumanizing societal pressure and culture.  Ionia is constantly striving for peace and balance...  But if history is anything to go by, that almost always leads to inevitable complacency, degeneracy or just outright corruption.

Zed is probably the greatest example of this. If it wasn't for Jhin's "art," then Zed would've never strayed on his own path, exposed himself to the forbidden shadows, doubted and betrayed the Kinkou Order, formed the Order of Shadows, rescued Kayn, formed an alliance with Syndra and so on.  He would've never started questioning Ionian society, philosophy and politics.  He would've never started seeing it for how backwards and archaic it truly is.  He would've never had a desire or a motivation to change any of it.  He'd probably just continue following the ways of the Kinkou Order in an effort to impress his father figure, much like Shen.

All in all, this really makes me wonder what he has in mind for Shen and Zed for his 'final masterpiece.'  Because at this point, I seriously doubt he just wants to kill both of them off and call it a day.
Does he want want both of them dead due to their past association with the old Kinkou Order, which was all about balance?  Is he leading them on a trail to uncover something even greater?  Is there more to Ionia's society and political system then we know - perhaps it's truly corrupt at its core and their philosophies of "peace" and "balance" is just one giant public facade?  Better yet, what about Jhin himself?  Was he too once a normal, mentally healthy individual until a traumatic event drove him insane, inevitably leading him to completely question and defy Ionia's traditional ways as well?  It's a lot to think about.

What _IS_ balance? 

It implies there are equal amounts or impact from different things.

If we have seen the order in Ionia....where is the 'chaos' then?

Think about Star Wars, and how the Jedi Order rose up. It too sought balance and became complacent. There was slavery for example in the republic, and the Jedi Temple spent more of its resources just keeping itself propped up as a symbol. Anakin Skywalker was by prophecy said to finally bring 'balance' to the force. He brought the Dark Side that was missing to shake apart the order, humble, and diminish it. 

But he failed. As things swung again out of balance fully to the Dark Side with the rise of the Empire. It was ultimately Anakin through his son, Luke who brought balance. Though The Last Jedi could have something to say about that.
It would have had to be at a young age, he mentions in his color story (or maybe bio) that he used to use blades from his father's martial arts training facility to make art rather than guns.
Phew, you get a cookie for that insight.
This is such an interesting find within the lore! Nice pick up, this is really cool!

I like this analysis. It's things like these that make me like the lore side of league and want to see more. What I want to see is more interactions with Shen and Jhin. We clearly see how Jhin affected Zed, but it is a lot more ambiguous with Shen. He was most definitely affected by Jhim ofc not as much as Zed was he still clearly believes in balance. Balance (Shen) vs Discord (Jhin)

So my takeaway from this is that the avant-garde and other pretentious "artiste" types are ultimately a bunch of sociopaths.

...which, if I'm being honest, I think I've always suspected on some level.
